title: Structural basis for NLP toxicity

author: Tea Lenarčič, National Institute of Chemistry Slovenia

segmentation: OK so hello, I'm very sorry to be your last lecture for today.
Is only me standing in your way for lunch?
So I will talk about structural basis for NLP toxicity.
I come from Ljubljana from National Institute of Chemistry.
Anne, I will just.
Shortly introduce the biological problem of NLP proteins.
It was very nicely explained in the morning and the plenary presentation of my mentor, Gregor Andalou.
Anyhow.
Ants are constantly confronted with a variety of abiotic and biotic stresses in nature.
And that's why they have to defend against this stress factors.
But it, unlike animals, they defend against unwanted stress factors on a cellular level.
Not like animals because animals have systematic system immune response.
So cells of plants are equipped with so-called PRR molecules.
Desire a receptor molecules, and they recognize specific pattern patterns on microbes, or the proteins that those microbes produce.
So after the recognition, this is a so-called pattern triggered immunity.
Gene expression comes and plants plant cells are defending against factors, trust factors.
So one type of proteins that plant recognize are.
NLP proteins.
These are these proteins activated this complex, but there are secreted by several feet of pathogenic microorganisms and there are found in fungi bacteria in all my sets.
But they have dual roles, so they activate plant immune system.
But they also cause leaf necrosis in dicot plants.
And into.

29 3 dimensional structure was solved and they found out that the structure was very similar to acting, appearance and acting opponents are cytolytic proteins that act by disrupting the cell membranes of target cells, of course, and appan specific binding to single mile in and because of this structural similarity, it was proposed that these two protein families share us common cytolytic pathway.
So.
Instead, just of recognizing a small part of those proteins BPR, so by this receptors, NLP.
Routines probably act directly with the membrane.
And they disrupt the membrane.
So are we, Sir.
Which was.
Divided in three parts, so we had to identify the lipid receptor.
Then we performed interaction studies and I will mostly talk about the structural analysis performed with extra crystallography.

So as Greg are already mentioned in the plenary presentation, the target molecules for NLP's in the plant membranes are so-called glycosyl, inaudible phosphorus eremites and they are constructed by ceramides with phosphate and the polar head group which contains different variety of sugar sugars.
So we found out that NLP proteins bind to the whole molecule to the whole GI PC, but we were very lucky to hear that NLP proteins also by own bank to this sugar residues at the end.
So the terminal sugar residues.
In Millimolar affinity, but it was still good enough for us.
So the NLP proteins bound to glucose, menan, manasam in.
OK, and this is the result, so this is a crystal structure of NLP.

Proteins in Gray is the Apple form of NLP protein, which was the structure that was already determined in 2009 and we solved two complexes of NLP with glucosamine and NLP with monosomy and you can see that the overall fold is stays the same, but there are some small conformational changes in the structure.
This is the electron density of the sugars.
It is not.
If anybody does actually crystallography, it is not really a perfect electron density.
In comparison to the rest of the protein electron density of the rest of the protein.

But we could still say that this election density belongs to the sugars, because we could see that in asymmetric unit there are four polypeptide change chains, and only the ones that had this additional electron density.
Had the structural changes.
That govern binding.
And you can see this one of the changes is this confirmation of the loop L3 in both cases.
And another conformational changes the coordination.
So if this magnesium ion as recited in the morning, the very important part of this protein structure is this coordination site.
And in Apple form this magnesium ion is coordinated by this set of amino acid residues.
While in complex structure this magnesium ions shift towards the interior of the protein, so this magnesium and get gets coordinated with a different set of protein of.
I mean I asked residues.

And you can see this Histidine 101 is directly involved in the coordination, but when the binding of the sugar occurs, this histidine is free and this histidine then later interacts with the sugar that came in the structure.
OK so besides this histidine there is also aspart eight 158.

So we performed point mutation of this binding site and the first we also observed this change in confirmation of loop L3 and we saw here that there is a conveniently placed tryptophan residues an the toxins that interact with the membranes usually use tryptophan residues for anchoring.
So when we change this tryptophan residue to alanine, we saw that this if this is a wild type.
Then the krosis.
If we change this tryptophan residue to alanine, we saw a reduce in like decrease in toxic activity.
So that means that the protein was not able to anchor in the membrane.
We also perform point mutation of this aspartame residue here, and when we change this Aspart 8 to alanine, we saw no decrease in toxic activity.
That means that the sugar could still come in because Allen has a smaller side chain.
But when we change the Aspart 8, two bigger residues like glutamate, glycine, phenylalanine and others we saw decreasing toxic activity because all of a sudden site chain.
Was in the place of the sugar and probably protein could not bind the Sugarhead group of GI PC's.
So yeah, we prepare recombinantly all these proteins and sometimes even the smallest change in the protein.
Is crucial for protein stability and protein secondary structure.
So we checked that this point mutations are really different from the wild type only because of point mutations and not thermal stability and the secondary structure and they were all the same.
So wild type.
And all the mutants have the same secondary structure and they have the same thermal stability.
And this is just another presentation of structural changes.
So this is the Apple formano pea protein.
This is the cavity to which sugar binds.
But after sugar banks to this cavity, you can see struck structural changes.
You can see that protein opens up and because of this change the protein is able to embrace the GI PC headgroup.
And this is the model we propose.
Again, Apple form, NLP, protein and bound form of NLP.
So you can see the structural change in this trip to fund residue that helps anchoring Daniel P protein.

But what we can see here is that this sugar head group is just big enough for this protein to embrace, but for instance dicot dicot plants have mostly this type of VIP season there in their membranes, but mana cards that are insensitive to NLP proteins have longer chains or their even branched.
So because of this different type.
Type of GI PCs present in the monocot plants.
The NLP proteins probably do not bind to them and do not cause necrosis.
And just short conclusions.
So we were talking.
And about natural killers of plant cells and we provided in this study the structural basis for NLP plant membrane interaction.
We also explained the NLP dicot plant selectivity and because this NLP's often attack economical economically important crops.
This is very suitable for a fighter pharmaceutical development in the future and with that I would just like to thank all of you for listening but mostly of course.
I meant to grander look Marika.
Katja Visnar Tina, the whole Department, and the German group.
We collaborated with them.
If you have any questions please.
Let me know.
